awd_titl_txt: Erwinia Pectic Enzyme Out System:  A Model for Studying     Exoprotein Secretion by Gram-Negative Bacteria
awd_abstract_narration: The exoprotein secretion ("Out") system of the plant pathogens                  Erwinia chrysanthemi and E. carotovora provide a promising                      experimental model for studying the translocation of proteins                   across the two membranes that envelope gram-negative bacteria.  The             bacteria selectively secrete a remarkable array of pectic enzymes               and other exoproteins.  A cluster of E. chrysanthemi "out" genes                enables Escherichia coli to secrete E. chrysanthemi exoproteins.                The E. chrysanthemi "out" genes are homologous with the pullulanase             secretion genes of Klebsiella pneumoniae, suggesting that the                   Erwinia model will be broadly relevant.  The two Erwinia "out"                  systems are conveniently specific for their respective exoproteins.             The objectives of this project are to complete the characterization             of the E. chrysanthemi "out" genes and encoded proteins by DNA                  sequence analysis and Tn5tac1 mutagenesis, identify the E.                      carotovora and E. chrysanthemi "out" components controlling                     exoprotein secretion specificity, and explore the secretion ability             of hybrid proteins and deletion derivatives involving E.                        chrysanthemi PelE and either E. carotovora Pel1 or beta-lactamase.                                                                                              An adequate understanding of the "out" pathway could lead to                    general techniques for either disrupting the secretion of virulence             proteins or enhancing secretion of beneficial proteins.
org_div_long_name: Division of Molecular and Cellular Biosciences
